etymology.description: 一 + 刀 — blade; tip of a blade; original form of 芒; later borrowed to mean “side”.
etymology.interpretation: Combines a horizontal line with a knife to picture the edge or tip of a blade, explaining the early sense “blade tip/awn.” That graph was later borrowed to write “side,” which broadened into modern senses like “square” and “direction.” It is unrelated to the “flag” graph 㫃.

examples.chinese: 我們繼續朝東南方向前進(我們繼續朝東南方向前進)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒmen jìxù cháo dōngnán fāngxiàng qiánjìn.
examples.english: We continue to advance toward the southeast direction.

examples.chinese: 這個地方很安靜(這個地方很安靜)。
桌上有一個正方形的盒子(桌上有一個正方形的盒子)。
examples.pinyin: Zhuō shàng yǒu yí gè zhèngfāngxíng de hézi.
examples.english: There is a square-shaped box on the table.
